bibl.title: Essay: Roger Post Ames, by [Paul L. Tate], [1954]

div1.p: [Tate] describes Ames involvement in the yellow fever experiments. Ames applied the mosquitoes, diagnosed the yellow fever patients, and provided exceptional medical care. Ames, fluent in Spanish, was able to persuade the Spanish volunteers to stay and undergo treatment.

div1.head: Essay: Roger Post Ames, by [Paul L. Tate], [1954]
div1.p:
In all the books and articles on the Yellow Fever Experi-
ment that I have read, the part Doctor Ames took has never
been fully recognized.

The mental picture one gets of Doctor Ames' work is that of
the doctor only. It causes one to think of a group of scien-
tific men applying the infected mosquitoes and blood drawn
from yellow fever patients to the volunteers. Then a number
of yellow fever experts make their diagnosis the next day and
transfer the patient to the yellow fever section, where Doc-
toe Ames takes over.

As I see the real picture, Major Reed had appointed Doctor
✓ Ames to complete charge of Camp Lazear as both Medical and
Military Officer. Every performance there except when Major
Reed was present, was his sole authority. He was the one who
was in complete charge of both Camp Lazear and the yellow
fever section.

He applied many of the infected mosquitoes used in the tests,
and most, probably all, of the blood transfusions. He was the
one who called in doctors Finlay, Guiteras, Albertini and
Gorgas for their diagnosis. Then, he was the one who, when
each of these “experts” feared to make the ticklish diagnosis
so early, made it himself, and transferred the patient to the
yellow fever section.

Next day he called these doctors in again, and his diagnosis
was invariably verified by all, thereby saving a very, very
precious day of treatment for the patient.

I understand that his medical treatment differed but slightly
from the standard technique used by other doctors at that
time. But his more than 67 patients, including those of Camp
Lazear, recovered. A record no other doctor has ever been
near to, as several such doctors have told me.

He was a doctor who used psychology in his treatment. He held
on to his nurse, Lambert, whom he had used in all his Cuba
cases.--A powerful young man who could handle the largest man
as gently as if he were a baby, and talked away the strange
fear that always haunt these patients, while gently restraining
them. Weaker nurses dragged and struggled with their patients
thereby inducing black vomit.

✓ Ames was the man who, with his fluent Spanish persuaded those
Spaniard patients to stay and undergo the treatment: Who visi-
ted the Corpsmen in their quarters, and talked many of them
to take the test. None of the first one knew if they would
contract yellow fever or not, but the rest of them knew damn
well they would, but Ames persuaded them nevertheless. I once
heard him say to a group on the barrack steps, “No doctor
should ask a man to submit to a disease unless he knows he can
cure him.” They all had confidence in Ames.

His psychology was illustrated in the case of a Spaniard
who was making a slow recovery. He kept this man's close
friend, though he had recovered from yellow fever, go to
his friend's bedside daily and jingle his bag of gold coins
and pour it from hand to hand and tell him that he would
have the same when he recovered. His friend got well.

He was the one who, himself recovering from yellow fever
when Lambert broke quararentine and came to him and told
of the trouble of Andrus, had Lambert and another man move
him on his bed to see what was wrong. He corrected the
trouble, and perhaps saved Major Reed's favorite case.

That is the Doctor Ames I see. Not simply a physician,
important as that is, but next to Reed and Lazear, the
most valuable man in the entire experiment. The one who
saved its demonstration from failure.
